a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, the time of the four rak'ahs is the highest forenoon [al-duha al-a'la] by which Allah, the Exalted, swore, saying: "By the forenoon [wa al-duha] and the night [wa al-layl] when it covers with darkness [idha saja]." In this oath is an indication to the greatness of the time in which the light [nur] of the heart [qalb] shines after the darkness of heedlessness [ghafla], just as the forenoon [al-duha] shines after the prostration [sujud] of the night [al-layl]. Thus, it becomes evidence that Allah, the Exalted, prepares for the soul [nafs] opportunities for manifestation [tajalli] and illumination [tanwir]. For just as the forenoon [al-duha] dispels the darkness of the night [al-layl], so too does spiritual wakefulness [yaqazah ruhiyyah] dispel the darkness of ignorance [jahl]. Therefore, it is incumbent upon the seeker [murid] to seize this time for prayer [salah] and remembrance [dhikr], so that expansion [inshirah] after constriction [dayq] and guidance [hidayah] after bewilderment [hayrah] may be realized for him.

a.g: And [by] the night when it covers with darkness,
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
And by the night when it settles [sajā], that is, when it becomes still, and its stillness is its calmness at this time, so no eye remains except sleeping, save for the Ever-Living, the Sustainer [al-Ḥayy al-Qayyūm] who neither slumber nor sleep overtakes Him. And it is said: when it settles [sajā] means when it extends and lengthens; and it is said: when it grows dark. Indeed, this oath by the night when it settles [sajā] confirms that the time in which creation becomes still and they are absent in sleep is the time of divine power [al-qudrah al-ilāhiyyah] which is established with the permanence of life [dawām al-ḥayāh] and overseeing creation. Therefore, it is fitting for the believer to utilize this time with remembrance [dhikr] and worship [‘ibādah] so that he may connect with the presence of holiness [ḥaḍrat al-qudūsiyyah] and feel the permanence of life [dawām al-ḥayāh] in his heart [qalb], so that this becomes a cause for the purification of the soul [tazkiyah al-nafs] and the realization of humility [taḥqīq al-khushū‘] in prayer [ṣalāh] and deeds.

a.g: Your Lord has not taken leave of you, [O Muhammad], nor has He detested [you].
And the Hereafter is better for you than the first [life].
And your Lord is going to give you, and you will be satisfied.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book10
And in the interpretation of His saying, the Most High: **"And your Lord will surely give you, and you will be satisfied"** [93:5], it is said: Muhammad will not be satisfied, nor will any one of his community [ummah] be in the Fire. And Abu Ja'far Muhammad ibn 'Ali used to say: "You, the people of Iraq, say the most hopeful [arja] verse in the Book of God, the Mighty and Majestic, is His saying: **'Say, "O My servants who have transgressed against themselves, do not despair of the mercy of God"**' [39:53] and the verse. But we, the People of the House [Ahl al-Bayt], say the most hopeful [arja] verse in the Book of God, the Most High, is His saying, the Most High: **'And your Lord will surely give you, and you will be satisfied'** [93:5]."

a.g: Did He not find you an orphan and give [you] refuge?
And He found you lost and guided [you],
And He found you poor and made [you] self-sufficient.
So as for the orphan, do not oppress [him].
And as for the petitioner, do not repel [him].
But as for the favor of your Lord, report [it].
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 5
Fourth: That making it public [al-izhar] is an establishment of the practice of gratitude [shukr], and indeed the Most High has said: "And as for the favor of your Lord, then proclaim it." And concealment [al-kitman] is ingratitude for the blessing, and God, Mighty and Majestic, has censured those who conceal what God, Mighty and Majestic, has given them, and coupled it with stinginess, saying, the Most High: "Those who are stingy and enjoin stinginess upon people and conceal what God has given them of His bounty." And He, peace be upon him, said: "When God bestows a blessing [ni'mah] upon a servant, He loves that His blessing upon him be seen." And a man gave something to one of the righteous in secret, so he raised his hand with it and said: "This is from the world [al-dunya], and openness [al-'alaniyah] in it is better, and secrecy [al-sirr] in matters of the Hereafter [al-akhirah] is better." And for that reason, some of them said: "If you are given in public, then take, then give back in secret, and gratitude [shukr] for it is urged." He, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever is not grateful to people has not been grateful to God, Mighty and Majestic." And gratitude [shukr] stands in the place of recompense, to the point that He, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever does you a kindness, then recompense him. If you are unable, then praise him well for it and pray for him until you know that you have recompensed him." And when the Emigrants spoke about gratitude, saying, "O Messenger of God, we have not seen people better than a people with whom we stayed; they shared their wealth with us until we feared they would take all the reward," He, peace be upon him, said: "All that you thank them for and praise them with is recompense."
